clinical_study.brief_title: Virtual Reality Intervention to Alleviate Breathlessness (COVID-19)
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Feasibility and Limited Efficacy of a Virtual Reality Intervention to Alleviate Perceived Breathlessness After Severe COVID-19 Pneumonia

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates the feasibility and limited efficacy of a Virtual Reality (VR) intervention to alleviate symptoms of perceived breathlessness and dyspnea in individuals recovering from severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

detailed_description.textblock:
Refractory breathlessness is the experience of breathlessness that persists despite optimal treatment of the underlying pathophysiology, and results in physical, psychosocial disability for the patient. As observed for SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV patients, a significant portion of COVID-19 patients present with persistent respiratory physiological impairment and refractory breathlessness that may not be addressed with conventional respiratory treatment such as oxygen, bronchodilators, diuretics or non-invasive ventilation.
Previous research on respiration-related feedback in Virtual Reality (VR) has demonstrated strong and replicable effects of VR feedback over one's perceived sense of agency and control over one's virtually embodied respiration. Based on these studies, the VR intervention evaluated here aims to alleviate symptoms of perceived breathlessness.
This within-subject study will compare breathing (dis-) comfort prior, during, and after a VR intervention that provides embodied visual feedback of participants' on-going respiration. Primary outcomes include subjective reports from participants (perceived efficacy, acceptability, and demand) and the intervention's clinical feasibility. Secondary outcomes include changes in respiration rate and variability as well as subjective ratings on perceived embodiment and sense of agency.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants perform both conditions. Condition order is randomised across participants.
study_design_info.masking_description: Participants know they will perform two conditions. They do not know the order and are naïve to the hypothesised effects.

primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of one year
primary_outcome.description: Subjective ratings depending on VR intervention. Visual Analog Scale from 0-10. For Comfort, higher scores present a better outcome. For discomfort, lower scores present a better outcome.

primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of one year
primary_outcome.description: Participant questionnaire and open feedback. Questionnaire items are on a 7 point Likert scale. Agreement indicates better feasibility, acceptance, and perceived outcome.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of one year
secondary_outcome.description: Change in respiratory rate depending on VR intervention. Respiratory rate (RR) is measured in breaths per minute. RR will be assessed with respect to baseline recordings.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of one year
secondary_outcome.description: Change in respiratory rate variability depending on VR intervention. Respiratory rate variability (RRV) is measured using inter-breath intervals (IBI). RRV will be assessed with respect to baseline recordings.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of one year
secondary_outcome.description: Subjective ratings depending on VR intervention. Questionnaire items are on a 7 point Likert scale. Agreement indicates stronger embodiment. Two control items are included that are not expected to change between conditions.

arm_group.description: All participants receive Virtual Reality feedback in two consecutive blocks, one condition per block (synchronous or asynchronous), randomised across participants.

intervention.description: Participants wear a respiration belt (Vernier, Go Direct) that continuously transmits thoracic circumference readings to a mobile phone (Samsung Galaxy S8) in real-time. The mobile device is placed in a headset (Zeiss VR ONEPLUS) and used to create a stereoscopic, immersive scene in Virtual Reality. The data from the respiration belt is used to map the on-going respiration pattern onto a virtual body in the scene in one of two feedback conditions: 1) synchronous: participants receive real-time feedback of their respiration, 2) asynchronous: participants receive asynchronous, frequency modulated feedback of their respiration.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Recovering from COVID-19 pneumonia
- Being able to give consent
- Being able to understand and speak French or English
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any unstable respiratory, neurological, and cardiac conditions
- Any psychiatric illness
- Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) score below 25.
